Item arrived much quicker than I expected with it not being a prime purchase. Looks brand new no dings, scratches and dents in the product I received. I am very happy with my purchase. I have wanted an IPad for a while but didn't want to pay that much for a new "toy" this was the perfect alternative to buying a new one. Would recommend in a heartbeat!
Superior product and still is, years later!!!

The Compromiser

  If you're someone who wants the name brand quality of Apple, but does not want to spend hundreds of dollars on a new IPad, then this is the ideal product for you. It can do everything that a new version can do, but costs under 100$ used. Also, If you have any other Apple products this is will be a lovely addition to your collection. You can sync it with your Mac, IPhone, or Apple watch and have all your apps and information together synced on the same cloud. It is perfect for the Apple aficionado on a budget looking for the best compromise between performance and price.

Tech Specs, Battery Life, and Durability

 While it may only be the second generation Ipad, it still has the very fast processing power of 1.0 GHz and 512 MB of RAM. You will not even notice you're using an older generation Ipad because it can also handle current ios software. It comes used, meaning it has a few minor scratches on the back, but this is not an issue if you're going to buy a case for it. With the case it looks, feels, and acts brand new!
 Even without the case this Ipad is extremely durable and can survive the wear and tear of life. You will notice it does not scratch easy as only the highest of falls or the deepest of cuts will penetrate its outer exterior and touch screen. The battery life is excellent as well; you can expect it to last all day on a nightly charge. Apple tech specs state that this device has a battery life of ten hours, and this is continuous usage of surfing the web, streaming, or playing music.

Final Considerations

 It comes safely sealed in custom made protective bubble wrap, therefore you can expect it to arrive safe and sound on your doorstep in two business days if you're a Prime member. It is not the biggest or the fastest Ipad to date, but buying used saves you anywhere from $400-$500 if you bought it new. Not only do you save hundreds, you also can do almost everything that the newer generations can do. If you're looking for a device for basic tablet uses such as streaming, surfing the web, listening to music, using apps, making Face time calls, checking email, etc. this Ipad will do it all.

Say what you want, but the Apple iPad 2 is fantastic. I don't know what it is about other android tablets, but they seem to have a limit on their usability. I have had my iPad 2 for about 4 years and I still use it to this day. I use it as a reader, browser, email, some mobile games, etc. It just works so flawlessly every time and it's super dependable. I'm a very active user and even the battery life is exceptional. Even years later, I can go days without the need to recharge the device. I also have a newer one (an iPad Air) that was given to me for Christmas and it's also great, but with the iPad 2, it just seems like they got everything right.

Not only is the iPad in perfect condition visually, it works perfectly too! Although it's an early model (2nd generation) it contains updated software so is compatible with every app I want to load. The camera also is amazing, considering this was the first iPad to have a camera. It's all in the software updates, which are truly awesome.

Had a small issue when, on day 2, the iPad stopped working and began to ask me for a passcode. I have an iTunes password, but it wanted a passcode. The former owner must have programmed one in and I could not get around it. Contacted the seller, who emailed me directions on how to restore the iPad to factory settings, and it has been working perfectly ever since.

If you are choosing between getting an inexpensive tablet or a used/refurbished iPad, don't hesitate to do the latter. Apple quality can't be beat. And although the seller did not state that this model was "refurbished", it was stamped as such when it arrived. Highly recommend!

I have been using this product for last 4 years now and it still continues to amaze me .
Till date I haven't experienced a single glitch. Lets get to the pros and cons:
Pros:
 * The touchscreen is sublime, but that's a known fact.
 * Apple user interface though restricted in many ways, is very simple and easy to use.
 * The iPad 2's design is simple but elegant and build quality is top notch (but always
 use it with a cover).
 * Don't go by the specs of this device, because my phone also has similar specs but
 when it comes to performance the iPad 2 just smokes my Xperia U.

Cons:
 * Movie viewing experience is average because of the format of the screen.
 * There are restrictions in Apple devices which some people won't like.
 * The biggest con perhaps is that the iPad 2 is now outdated. Two versions have
 succeeded the iPad 2. It's more wise to spend a few thousands more and go for
 the iPad 4 which will come out soon.

The iPad 2 or any other iPad for that matter, is a great companion, a fun device which you can buy if you have extra money to spend. However if you need to do hardcore work, go for laptops

Pros: light & thin (impressively thin), great battery life (10 hours of use as advertised), screen is big, clear, and sharp.  The guts (cpu, ram, etc.) are quick and stable.  Sensitivity is great.  With a full wrap case, it responds to every touch.  Sturdy and durable, but with a case it's even better. Love this thing (and no I'm not an apple fan boy, used to be anti Apple but products like this got me hooked!)

Cons: speaker.  The speaker is pointed away from the user.  Which makes it quite for the user and louder for everyone around th user.  Need external speaker for music and what not, and head phones if you are planning to use it while others watch tv or whatever.  Also the storage is sort of small.  I'd say it's worth the extra $ for a bigger hard drive.  64 is best value, but the 32 is decent.

This IPad is fantastic!  Insanely thin, yet still very sturdy.  Screen is sharp, and clear.  As to its size, it's as big as I can be, and still be portable.  Comfortable and big enough for adult size hands, yet still small enough for my 6 year old to use.  Extremely light! And the battery life is great.  I didn't believe that it would really have a 10 hour battery life as advertised, but I sit here corrected.  The battery is no joke and really gives you 10 hours of actual use.  My only hang up (with all I (pad, touch, phone etc.) is the speaker.  While it produced sharp crisp sound it is pointed away from the user.  This diminishes the volume levels a lot as far as what you hear while using it, while it is extremely loud to any one sitting around you.  If I want to watch something or play a game while my wife is watching tv, I have to use head phones.  The sensitivity on the touch screen is perfect.  Not sure yet if you can adjust it or not, but it's at a perfect level just the way it is.  It is sensitive enough that with a full case/ screen protector it reacts to every touch still.  I would recommend strongly to buying a great quality full protection case, and decent external speaker, and a good set of head phones.  As far as storage, the 32 gig should be the minimal.  I can fill up 16 gigs very quickly, so it's worth it even for casual use to get something bigger than the 16 gigs.  64 gig is the best value, but the 32 is still respectable.  So far so good.  I love this thing.  Bought it for my son, but fell in love with it.  Buying a second one for myself!

I recently bought the I-pad 2 in order to attempt to keep up with school. It offers fantastic apps for keeping up with school as well for entertainment. The device also offers great battery life as well as portability
The I-Pad is backed by the app store which is the central hub for application developers to create some incredibly useful tools. The app store shines when it comes of ease of use. Instead of having to go through pages on internet to find a specific application that I need I can quickly find them through the app store and they will be supremely cost efficient as well.
 Allowing application developers an open platform to present some of their amazing ideas doesnt only assist with school; it can also lead to fun and often addictive forms of entertainment. The I-Pad comes backed with apples I-Tunes giving you an infinite selection of music to download and play. If you don't want to pay the small fee either you can download other applications that allows you to listen to music for free. They also offer a wide array of movies that are played with excellence 10 inch screen size.
 The I-Pads versatility is not to be overlooked either. Its compact size allows for great portability without needing a laptop bag or anything to big. . Its battery life is incredibly long lasting me 2 days at times without a charge using it in almost every class and studying from 8 AM to 6PM. Though I do recommend that you should put some sort of protective case over it because it can be quite fragile. There is an also an issue presented that if it does run of battery that it may actually stay off and won't turn back on unless you do a factory reset. This means you lose all of your data but with cloud storage this doesnt pose that huge of a problem.
The I-Pads few glitches pale in comparison to the benefits this product can offer. For a student like myself it has been one of my main tools for studying, doing homework, or taking notes in class. The seemingly endless list of applications and songs offer unlimited entertainment as well. The portability and batter life only add to its ease of use as well.

If you are international students who are considering to purchase the first tablet, this review is very useful! It is because I was in the same situation like you two years ago, and now I am very glad that I purchased the iPad.

Unlimited Books Can Be Purchased From Anywhere
As an international student, I believe you wished that you could read more books in your first language. An iPad will solve your problem! When I started using it for the first time, I was skeptical about reading books with the tablet. However, surprisingly, it was very easy to read. The size of screen is big enough and the size of fonts can be adjusted so that it was so much more comfortable to read books on iPad than on iPhone.

These days, I even believe that reading ebook on iPad is more convenient than on paper version because most of books can be purchased online, and they are cheaper than the paper version. Once books are purchased, all of them will be downloaded on your iPad permanently so that you do not need to carry many books from your home country any more!!

Great Support for Classes
Heavy reading assignments are challenging for international students. However, my iPad has been very useful for those assignments. For example, if there is an unfamiliar vocabulary on a homework PDF file, iPad gives you the translation of the word by simply touching it. Therefore, you can keep reading the file without guessing the meaning of unfamiliar words. In addition, since iPad is quite light, and the battery lasts about 10 hours without charging, you can access to reading materials anywhere and anytime. Because of this portability, you can read assignments in a small portion at a time instead of reading files in front of a computer for many hours.

I have been using my iPad every day since I purchased it, and I cannot imagine my school life without having it. This is how much my iPad helped my college life and that is why I am giving 5 stars for the evaluation. If you want to read books in your first language or have difficulty of reading assignments, I highly recommend you to purchase the iPad. It is a powerful tool to change your college life dramatically. By using it, I hope you will have a wonderful time studying overseas!!

I've been having this iPad for three years now going to four years now
I have to tell you now
I have barely experience any faults or mishaps with it
It's still functioning as well as it was when I bought it
It's really durable
Efficient and portable
It has a fast response to touch sensitivity
The only downer would be that sometimes it freezes and takes time to return back to normal
Also one piece of advice
Always back up your information on iCloud
Because one day my iPad turned off after it froze
And I had to connect it to iTunes on my laptop
And have to start again
My last back up was seven months ago
So I had to do a lot of work to derive all my information back again
So beware of that
The only fault you should watch out
For is the freezing
Also the battery life is amazing
It last longer if you reduce the brightness of the screen
I charge once a day now and it last throughout the whole day
I am also a college student
So it really helps me for writing projects, reading projects, designing projects, typing essays and papers
I would highly recommend this device to Anyone looking for something effective efficient and durable

Received my iPad 2 32GB AT&T refurbished. I chose to buy the iPad as I already had an iPhone. It Arrived within 4 days. (Opted for free shipping.) Cosmetically you cannot tell it is used. It looks & operates like it's Brand New!! In my opinion, It runs excellent!!  I would highly recommend this seller. I am extremely happy with this purchase and for the reasonable price!  I found out it does not come equipped with a SIM card. Also, if you run it off of wifi, you don't need a SIM card. I called AT&T they explained that you don't necessarily need a SIM card. If you want to pay for monthly service, they will give you a SIM card for free. Prepaid monthly service  is about $50/mo. Then you would have wifi while roaming. Overall, pleased with my purchase and definitely money well spent.  -Julie P  Hartford CT

Even though this ipad is four years old it still makes us happy and I am surprise that even though technology advances so fast this has not gotten old, the model I have is wifi only because I could not afford cellular data plan back then, now I got an iPad mini with cellular from tmobile store.

First lets go with the cons
Cons:
You cannot sync music to ipod or other MP3 players.
Does not have flash support but can be added through a third party browser.

Now let's go with the pros
Pros:
Good battery life.
Nice screens.
Internet speeds.
Just as Productive as a heavier laptop.
Plenthora of apps available to both of our iPads.
Fun gaming.
Responsive screens.
And good for education and business.

Conclusion: this is some of the high end tablets in the market, so to say, if you have the money I highly recommend an ipad and if you have the money I would recommend the 3G or cellular model.

The iPad 2 is a great product.  I bought a Zagg keyboard to attach to the iPad and my life has been great.  The iPad is a great tool for communicating, running apps, surfing the web, and reading email.  I do wish apple would have included siri with the iPad.  Hands free interaction with the device would have been helpful on the move.  It could have been so much more.

I run numbers, facebook, pages, and instant messaging on the iPad.  I like iMovie editing and found the software to be very reliable on the hardware.  You will need to buy ear head set to listen to music.  The built in speakers are not very loud.  The microphone is adequate but not great.  I found the dragon voice recognition system made too many errors to be useful.  I use webreader to listen to my stories.

iPhoto is great.  I wish it could find people by voice command.  This is a feature I look forward to using.

Email interface is great.  You send alot of time tapping to remove obsolete emails

No viruses.  Yeah

IBooks works well on the iPad.  I wish that iBooks was capable of reading your ebook

Microsoft remote desktop works on the iPad2.  I wish that rd worked with a tap interseption capability rather than a drag and arrow click.  It takes time to navigate.

the iPad 2 screen is ok.  It smears easily.  A new nano material that resists smearing needs to be developed.

Ignorance is bliss. I work at BestBuy and people always ask me "APPLE or ANDROID." Of course it depends on the user and most people who come in the store weren't technologically savvy. So, the majority of people wanted something easy to pick up and learn. Therefore, the majority of my recomendations were the iPad. I am in college and I have an internship. Both of these roles I use the iPad in. I am even using my iPad right now. I have a Macintosh computer and I found myself using my iPad for the majority of my computing needs. The iPad has also paid itself off by the cost of Text Books alone. Every book I get on my iPad saves me on average about $100. E text books are much cheaper than buying books on campus. I also have a keyboard case which they sell on Amazon for less $50.00. I use an app called Pages, which is an Apple developed app, that allows me to edit, import and export Word Documents. Not to mention its movie and music capabilities. I also invest heavily and the iPad has made my life so much easier when it comes to managing my investments and banking. Overall, the iPad has been a life saver for me and my family. Also, another great product that is a must have is a Zagg Invisible shield. They are a little difficult to put on but they have instructional videos on how to do it. Thanks for reading.

I bought this iPad to use for college and have never regretted it! I use it every day for school, flying and work! I connect my GPS to the ipad through bluetooth and use it every time I fly somewhere or go on a long car trip. I would recommend to anyone looking for a tablet!

I have been looking for a new tablet for a few weeks now. Its hard to know what to look at or choose because there are so many different ones. I finally decided that I was just going to forget about it. Why do I need a new tablet when I still have my ipad 2?

You see all these tablets that claim this and that and have thousands of things they can do. Im actually sick of reading about all of them! My ipad already does all of those things. I used mine all through community college now Im in university and I still use it hours every day. I have friends that have other kinds of tablets. One of them has the newest ipad that I like but I was also thinking about a newer kindle which another of my friends has. The kindle is nice and so is the new ipad but when looking at the screens and then looking at my ipad I LIKED my ipad2 screen better than theirs. The colors are better. IDK why. Even my friend said that the color on mine was better than her new ipad even though that one has the newer screen.

Ive had mine for 3 years. Although its older, its still great as the new ones just not as great of a screen. The one thing I dislike is the cameras are not as great as some other tablets but I still take a lot of beautiful pictures though. But everything else is great. So, I finally realized that if I was going to buy a new tablet right now I might even buy an ipad 2 again because of how cheap they are now.

The iPad2 is in near new condition. Even though this is my first Apple product I have become rather proficient in using it. It is a step up from my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 when using it on the internet, but the Kindle has been truly reliable and easy to use.
The unit arrived with a 3% battery charge so I plugged in the charger and came back to it the next morning to find it at only 74% charge. So I left it for another 24 hours while I searched the net for iPad2 battery issues. It seems everyone feels that these units are slow to recharge. When it finally reached a 100% charge I started learning how to use it. This is not a toy, it really is a computer and has many features that are not readily apparent so I bought an "iPad For Dummies" book on Amazon to help me get the most out of my unit. I recommend this to anyone new to an iPad. Recharges now take less time than before. I paid $214.99, including shipping, for this unit and feel like I saved 50% over a new unit. I surf the web, do emails, read my Kindle books on it and am now searching the available Apple apps.
I feel really great about this purchase and the unit. I worked for a large computer company for 38 years and always had a company laptop or whatever, so going to an Apple product was a big deal for me. Take the plunge!

I can not say enough good things about this tablet. I love it and more so the ease at which I can carry it around vs a laptop. Battery life is superb compared to my laptop and the picture is as well.
But what really makes this so useful are all the applications you have for it and how easily you can call them up. Want to send an email or check the ones you have waiting. Easy. Want to play a video game Easy. Do you subscribe to a magazine and have a few minutes and you want to read it. Easy. Listen to music. The same. Take a beautiful and I mean beautiful picture and send it to someone quickly. Easy. Children around and you want to make a little video of them. Easy. I could go on and on and on. But the bottom line is EASY. And for what $300 or so. You can't miss.

This things been reviewed to death, so I won't talk about specs, capabilities, etc., but I wanted to tell a quick story of why I'll be using these things for as long as Apple make them. I got this when it first came out. I'm IT savvy(ish), and knew how to set the thing up. At the same time, I gave my Windows Netbook to my lovely mother :-)  It was her first time with a computer and it didn't go well. Now don't get me wrong, I love Windows and use it every day, but it's hard explaining to a 75 year old why you need security updates and a reboot, or why something is stuck in the Outbox, or many other occurrences.
Ultimately, I decided to upgrade to a newer iPad (go iPad Air!), and I took the Netbook from her, and gave her this instead. Sure, I set up a few things like email, etc. and had to tell her that "Safari is now your Internet Explorer", but then she was off!
The point is that these things are just so intuitive, that almost anyone can just work them out. For anyone thinking of getting someone older (or maybe even younger), into using the Net, etc., I can't recommend this enough.
EXCELENTE PRODUCTO

I love my iPad.  Previously I had a kindle fire which I loved also until I tried an iPad my wife brought home from her work...I was hooked.  Graphically it is far superior to the kindle fire in my opinion.  Absolutely love the fact that the calendar, photos, etc...will sync with my iPhone.  The available apps from Apple far exceed anything amazon has to offer.  I'm am a freelance graphic designer and love the amount of helpful design apps available on the apple store. If you are currently looking for an amazing product that is very reliable then you are looking at it right now. This Ipad 2 is very easy to use and can be used for almost anything. Whether you are at home and just want to play games or watch Netflix or if you are at school and want to take notes, this Ipad can do just about anything. Many people have consumed and reported their personal experiences and for the most part if you own an Ipad 2 you cooler than everyone else who doesnt own one. People will look at you at work or in class and envy you since they don't have one. That is a fact! I encourage everyone to own one of these. It is a purchase I do not regret and I would recommend it to anyone. My whole family owns one from my sister to my cousins and nephews and we are all satisfied with the Ipad 2. It works as a mini computer on the go and you will love it.
 This item is fun to use and is very appealing. The size and weight of it allows you to be able to take anywhere with you. It is much thinner and it has been created to be much faster than other tablets. You will not have to wait for 10 minutes to allow it to turn on , you will be guaranteed fast service from this apple product. There are also multiple languages from which you can choose from to The display of the Ipad is just phenomenal. Its glossy widescreen allows you to see everything very nicely. Theres no doubt the resolution quality is the best! You would want to take pictures and videos everywhere you go. This Ipad has also been created with front and rear cameras so you don't have to only take pictures of others but you can take pictures of yourself. How awesome! So if you and your friend want to take a picture but there is no one around that can do you the favor, there is no need to worry about it because you have this ipad. Adjust the camera to face you and snap away. You can also fix the picture by adding filters or purchasing apps that allow you to fix a picture in anyway whether its adjusting the color and brightness or adding funny stickers or borders. There are thousands of apps you can find that are fun and very useful. Many apps you must pay for but they are usually very cheap and definitely worth it. There are also many free apps that are your usual apps. The app store has thousands of apps specifically for ipads. This allows you to have an enjoyable time when using your ipad. When purchasing your ipad, your item comes with free built in apps. These apps include the camera, calendar, clock, safari and many more general apps you need on a everyday basis. Surfing the web on your Ipad can not get any easier. It was created so that everyone can easily learn from your 4 year old sister to your 70 year old grandmother. The buttons on the exterior of the ipad include the home, volume, and silence key and the hold button. The power and battery life of the ipad is excellent. You can go hours of surfing the web or playing games without having to keep charging it everyday.  For example, I recently went on a trip to San Francisco which took 6 hours. I watched movies on the way there and movies on the way back and didn't have to chrage it during my vacation. It was amazing to be able to use it for so long and not have to keep charging it on my trip. On my trip I was also able to factime my brother who was back at home. With the ipad you can videochat and factime anyone at anytime as long as you have wifi. This allows you to have contact with someone you haven't seen for a while. It allows you to be able to see someone while talking to them at the same time. This for me is the best part of the ipad since It clearly allows me to see my brother who lives far away from me. The Apple Ipad 2 is an excellent product overall. If you are still debating whether or not to purchase an Ipad 2 you should go and play with one hands on first before purchasing. You can go to best buy or an Apple store to witness this marvelous item in action. I give the Ipad 2 five stars because I love it. It is very reliable for anything and the design of it makes it easy to use anywhere you go!

I'll mix it up a little and start with the things I don't like about the iPad 2. I sold my iPad 2 a while back, but I now have an iPad 3 and iPad Air. 4 iPhones, and an iMac.  On the other side of the fence I own a Kindle Fire HDX 7", and did own a 7" Lenovo tablet, both of which I like also.  Obviously the only draw-back I can think of with the iPad 2 is the poor resolution, which probably isn't even that big of a deal to some people. To me it's a deal breaker, and that is why I sold my iPad 2, however when I got the iPad 3 and realized how much heavier it was, I actually kind of regretted getting rid of my older version!  I absolutely love the light weight of the 2, ALMOST as much as I love the Retina display of the successive models.  I honestly can't tell any real difference in the speed of the 2, vs. the 3, vs even the Air! I guess I'm not all that much into games anymore, which is probably the only place the upgraded power and speed of the newer iPads would ever come in to play anyway!

  As I mentioned before, the Retina display to me is a very worthwhile tradeoff even for a heavier iPad.  I actually prefer my iPad w/ Retina and keyboard case to a much more expensive Mac book Air, without Retina display. The reason being, no matter how close you set the iPad to your eyes (such as laying in bed with it sitting on your chest, the clarity is just like reading printed material right out of a book, and to me that's more important than a big screen any day of the week! I much prefer the new fire wire charging cables over the 32 pin one that the iPad 2, android tablets, and other phones use.  I hate having to worry about which side is supposed to be up or down...

  The reason I would go with an iPad 2 over any of the other Android tablets, including the Kindle Fire, even though probably all the android tablets have far superior hardware for the same amount of money, is that iEnvironment. iOS, iTunes, iCloud, better quality apps, even from the exact same software on iOS vs. Android.  Owning something from Apple is not about a status symbol or anything like that for me, to me it's like owning a piece of art that makes my heart go pitter-pat every time I pick one up or sit down to relax with one on my chest.  My satisfaction and joy of owning and using such device with such a OS and compatibility with everything in my book is well worth the extra money that Apple charges for their devices.  I'm also very proud to support an American company, versus a Chinese or Korean one... sorry, but do you haters even stop to think that all the Chinese and Korean equipment use poorly paid and poorly cared for cheap labor in China just like Apple does... duh!

I got this iPad in October 2011, according to the engraving on the back, and since 2 years seems to be the extent of most gadgets' life these days, I simply had to make a review. A good one, of course.

PROS:

Weight: By far, the most amazing thing about this tablet is that it weighs so little. I believe it weighs less than any other iPad out there, which is weird, but I think the iPad mini is supposed to cater to those who have a problem with that. The iPad isn't meant to be held in one hand, though. It's a real personal computer, only in tablet from, and you must treat it as such. If you need to be able to read in bed or something, get a kindle or iPad mini. However, you'll find that the iPad is very convenient for most uses.

Design: The front of the iPad is defined by a single pane of multitouch glass - and a home button. The back is made of aluminum. There is a front camera, a rear camera in the top right corner, and a speaker at the bottom. This simplistic design, which Apple litigiously fought for against Samsung, is in a word, magical. I'm not too much into the marketing stuff, but seriously, there is something extremely premium about Apple products, and I am sure it is more than the pseudo philosophical marketing. The Smart Cover actually works really well, though its necessity is... debatable. Overall, this tablet feels like its worth 500 dollars. Ok, so it's 400 now, but you know what I mean.

Durability: The primary user of this tablet is an unhygienic now-9-year-old who is not exactly dexterous and immediately gets on it after school, sin lavar sus manos. If you know glass, you know that the only thing that can really scratch it are minerals. That's right. Not knives or cleats, though they may if you try hard enough. It's finger salts, salt from food, dust, dirt, sand, jewelry like diamonds and quartz. However, today I wiped off all the prints with a damp hand towel and I could count, I kid you not, 3 micro scratches. That's amazing. This tablet has been dropped, probably not from extreme heights, but still. The glass at the corners, along with the aluminum housing, is tattered. There are several deep scratches in the aluminum on the back. However, there are no functional damages to this tablet. That's also very nice. You probably don't need the Smart Cover for its protective aspect. You will however, want it so you can use it for support. It helps a lot.

Display: Eek. I'll kick it to you straight; the resolution of this screen is terrible. If your going to be looking at pictures, you're going to be disappointed. 1024x768 doesn't cut it. My 4.5 inch S2 had a resolution of 800x640. I thought it was sub par, but acceptable. The iPad is just bleh. It's colors are amazing though. I don't know too much about outdoor performance, but I've never felt that brightness was an issue, so it's probably ok. What the iPad lacks in detail more than makes up in size. Laying down in bed with a ten inch screen feels so empowering. I feel like I have all the media in the world in my hands, and I almost do.

Apps: I don't use my iPad for work. It stays at home most of the time, and at home, I have my desktop. I would assume it would be pretty easy to use iWork to create, but I wouldn't know. *flame alert* I believe Android is better for smartphones, and iOS for tablets. There is a serious lack of tablet apps for android, but I am continually surprised at the growing iOS tablet app ecosystem. However, there are a greater variety of apps on Android, in my experience. The iPad can actually handle games pretty well, despite its age. That all I really need to say. There isn't any calculator or weather or stocks app, but you'll find great alternatives in the App Store.

Camera: Why are you reading this? What are you doing with your life? Why would you want to use the iPad's camera for anything except FaceTime? Seriously? Well, that's all you're going to be able to do, because the cameras on the 2 are terrible. Really. I would expect more for 500 bucks, but whatever. It's not a priority. If you ever find yourself in so dire a situation that you need to use the iPad camera, you better invest in a disposable, or something.

Battery life: Ho ho. Tee hee. The battery life of the 2 makes me want to giggle. Even 2 years later, the battery life still feels virtually infinite. I can almost guarantee you, you will never have a problem with the iPads battery life. This is because if the square cube principle. The surface area (screen size) increases at rate of the dimensions, squared. The volume, cubed. More volume means more battery. So, theoretically, the bigger the device, the longer the battery life. Oh, and iOS is super efficient, almost forgot that.

Performance: Welp, iOS7 is here. Anybody with anything older than 2012 must upgrade to escape the lag! Not so. Though the animations in iOS7 are super slow and can induce "motion sickness", the iPad 2 handles it pretty well. (I swear, auto correct has something against the word we'll.) The gaming isn't bad for such an old device, though I have yet to try out newer games like asphalt 8. However, you'll be able to stream video (not in hd, of course!) and play 2d games  with no hitches. The keyboard does sometimes take a while to pop up and apps do take somewhat longer to load, but hey, we're talking about an old geezer tablet here.

Features: I haven't been able to use Bluetooth to transfer files yet, presumably because Apple wants me to upgrade and use AirDrop. Classic Apple. And I'm pretty sure Siri could easily run on the 2. Oh well, looks like we're stuck with... The two doesn't have any gimmicks, per se, to it. It has the dual cameras, but that's about it. There is nothing to show off. Just to experience. FaceTime is great, though. Like, wow. It's really the best video chat technology I've ever seen. If nothing else, I would commend apple on its FaceTime infrastructure. It's simple and fun and convenient, not to mention powerful.

Overall: Even after 2 years of not so nice treatment, my 2 is functionally perfect. It really feels amazing to be able to consume content on such a big screen. The thinness and lightness of the device make it disappear as you're using it. FaceTime really is the best interpersonal video chat platform as of today. IOS 7 runs fine on this, but don't expect to be so lucky next year. I was actually shocked to see the price here on Amazon. Really? 400 bucks for a 2011 tablet? When the 5 is just around the corner and will cost only 100 more? Only a fool would buy it now. However, the 2 really bolstered the image of Apple I had. I have a first gen Nano that actually still works for a whole day! I would expect the iPad to do the same. This review isn't recommending that you buy the 2. All I'm saying is that Apple makes the best tablets out there. Even the most hardcore Android fanatic (which I am dangerously close to) could agree on some levels. iPads are feat for consuming content. Maybe even for creating. However, if you want to get real work done, you're going to want to wait for the next generation of windows 8 pro tablets with Broadwell Chips in them. I need an IDE to be able to do programming when I go to college, and the fact that no such software is available for iOS means that I can't take this there. The iPad isn't a complete replacement for a real computer. But it comes pretty darn close.

Sent from my iPad

I purchased this for my 3 year old son as an upgrade to his ipad 1. He has been very proficient at using ipad from a very early age. itunes store has a huge selection of learning apps for his age group and younger. My son has been a ipad and ipod user sinc he was about 9 months old, he thinks he is playing, but he is really learning. He is way ahead of where he should be and he has had a ton of fun doing it. After ios 6&7 came out his ipad 1  was no longer able to keep up with the technology of the upgraded apps. I purchased the 64g ipad 2 so he would have plenty of room for his apps since some of the apps can be large downloads. i am able to also to limit what he is able to do in settings and the app store. He can only get apps ifi unlock it. ipad 2 was easy to child lock certain features and content. ipad 2's long battery is great on trips, it keeps him busy and i don't need active wifi for his apps to work. I wish that ipad existed with my other children. I like that he is learning on current to future technology that most daycares or preschools can not provide.  I recommend this to any parent. The ecpense is worth it. A childs education id priceless. ipad 2 is perfect for facilitating that.

I have resisted getting a tablet for years. As others have observed, a computer without a real keyboard is weighted toward content consumption rather than content creation (otherwise known as work). To fill the need for a lightweight, long battery life, zero fan/vent portable, I had purchased a Chromeook. Frankly, after the novelty wore off, it was sitting in the drawer more than on my lap.

Well a month or so ago, on a whim I got the iPad 2. Within 24 hours of playing with it and discovering both powerful productivity (like aTimelogger and DayOne) and music apps (such as Synthesia, Garage Band) that fill voids in what I've seen as an owner of an Android phone, I became a devoted member of the iPad cult. From there, I tested several keyboards and have settled on the Kensington Ultimate and Logic Fabricskin.

Now, after month downrange, it smile on my face hasn't worn off -- the iPad and I are inseparable. It is really an integral part of my life and work.

I will probably sell the Chromebook on eBay. This will be the first of many iPads to come as they come out with newer versions.

I have been an owner of an Apple iPad 2 (64GB AT&T 3G) since the date of it's first released in the US on March 11, 2011. After more than two years of heavy use both personally and professionally I can say the Apple iPad changed my life. It is without a doubt one of the most innovative, useful, and powerful products on the market. That was true in April of 2010 when Apple released the first iPad, and it remains true to this day. An unimaginable number of iPad reviews exist online, so I will not restate the specs or the seemingly endless uses and applications. I will simply state that I have never regretted my purchase of my iPad for one second and I have found it to be one of the most versatile, useful, and simple pieces of technology I have ever owned. It's multipurpose functionality cannot be overstated. I cannot speak highly enough of the Apple iPad - and look forward to the day when I can upgrade to the latest model. Even so, my iPad 2 continues to be fully functional, fast, and sturdy. Why wait - BUY APPLE!

I bought several things on the web, things that were considered "NEW" and actually they weren't.

This time everything changed, the product was literally new, no use at all and I saved a lot of money.

I've been a long term Apple customer and will be forever.

(Caveat: I'm not a techie dude (though I do enjoy some techno music... go figure, right?) so proceed cautiously with my review...)

I've been brought to the iPad dragging my heels, kicking and screaming, like a bratty toddler told to eat his peas (I hate peas).

My history: I've not been a fan of the proprietary and I love music.  Some years ago, before my kids bought an iPod... I owned a Creative Zen Vision M MP3 player... 60 gigs that thing carried... and I could download whatever I wanted into it... no proprietary poo and nobody needed to know my financial information or address, and I loved that lil device for that freedom.  Creative created a great product, and in fact they own a couple of patents that enable certain Apple products to work, but like Beta recording tape... a technology that was superior to VHS, yet it was popularity of the lessor product that eventually killed the chances of the better device ever really taking hold.  Similarly, from a freedom point of view.. seems like much of the MP3 market has gone the way of the dinosaur, losing out to the proprietary Apple name.  And so begins my review.

To recap: I hate proprietary.  And Apple IS that: proprietary.  Having said this, and yielding to my better senses, I have made allowance to bend towards the Apple by initially purchasing my iPhone.  I still hate the proprietary... love the device; Apple, begrudgingly liked by me for the things they build, made such a great device in the iPhone that I decided to take the leap by swallowing the whole schtick and bought this iPad.

This second generation, 16 gig, iPad purchase was a big one for our family... actually, for my wife (as a birthday present to her), and she's been tethered to it for two days... loves it.

It's a nice sized tablet... much easier to surf the internet with a larger screen than that of an iPhone, so that's a nice plus.  As for their proprietary... if you move to Apple with the purchase of your own iPad, you'll have to give them information... personal information, to include credit card, and normally that's enough to stop me in my tracks, so if you're like me and don't easily want to part with giving this info out... this isn't the tablet for you.  But before you consider not buying this tablet for that reason, remember that once you do give in, you're introduced to a world of great products and support.

As far as functionability... this iPad is basically a picture/video taking wi-fi accessing internet surfing tool (nice run-on).  Conceptually, the tablet is intuitive in it's function... if you already own an iPod/iPhone/iPad.... yet if you don't, navigation/use of this tablet is pretty easy to learn... easier still if you have someone that owns one helping you for the first 2 mins.

What makes this device interesting is the ability to add applications (apps) that enable you to do a millions things with this device.  Some apps are free while some cost money... and they're found once you hit the "App Store" icon on your device.

My iPad was purchased with the wi-fi connectibility option only; I wasn't interested in purchasing (another...) 3g AT&T smart device usage fee, though it's an option (another model...).  As for internet connectibility, I just have to find a wi-fi site and wahla... connection, at no extra cost to me.  Sure, this doesn't make the tablet very usable while in motion, but that's not a big deal for my usage intent... so this really doesn't effect me as it would someone who's occupation relies on such mobility usage (did that make sense?  Hope so...).

This tablet comes with 16 gigs of memory (same as my phone...); I have hundreds of photos and some video on my phone, but no music.  If you have an ample music collection you would like to carry/keep on this iPad, I might suggest you purchase one with a higher storage capability.  This iPad will be used by my wife and she's going to stick pictures on it, perhaps SOME music, but not much between the two; for her, 16 gigs is just right.

As for other functions: it's got a camera (don't ask me for specs... look them up.  New generation iPads have newer iris'/greater photo capabilities), that can also take video.  I can do a video type conferencing with another Apple device (another iPhone/iPad, for example)... it's called "facetime"... that's a neat feature that my 4 year old loves when I'm at work for two days or more at a time.  Battery life seems good... charging is a snap; USB or wall... you can do both with hardware supplied.

Importantly, and to their credit... Apple does a great job supporting their products (my experience with a problematic iPhone, handled by Apple Care... was top-notch).  They take care of warrantied items very well.  An additional note: Apple stores, if you 've got one close-by... are a great resource for handling warranty/problematic software issues... so the support for the product, in-store or not, is there.

As for iPads or tablets in general... there are others, but even this second generation iPad makes internet connection, and use, a breeze.  After owning now... two devices, I'm a believer in the products that Apple (thus far...) have made... and though I STILL don't dig the proprietary thing, it's a reasonable trade-off for being able to use a pretty great device.

I hope this review assists you in making your choice, whichever that choice may be.  Thanks for listening.

In November, I purchased the iPad Mini, which, was my first iPad.  I was thrilled to death to have it, and after a few months, I knew that I wanted a larger screen and more GB, so, I spent time trying to find out whether or not I wanted to spend for the iPad 4.  After some thought, I decided to get an iPad 2, since the mini and this one were built the same.  I am not disappointed.  As soon as I added the upgrade, I was able to use Siri, even on the iPad 2.  I personally can't tell the difference between Retina display or not, so, I am pleased with this purchase.  You can't go wrong.

When I bought my iPad, it was a complete splurge. I was at the apple store to fix a operator-error with my iphone and asked about the iPad. I originally thought that it was just an overgrown iPod touch, but the more I learned about it, the more I realized that it seemed to be a small computer. The iPad has Bluetooth capabilities and I bought a Bluetooth keyboard to go with the iPad. I am still wrapping my head around the iPad and all its features. I really enjoy the iCloud, allowing me to sync up my iPhone and iPad. One of the first apps I downloaded was Pages and it has been fantastic. One of my biggest concerns regarding the iPad is the accessibility to remove documents, pictures,etc off of the iPad. There is no USB port, so I cannot hook up a zip-drive and due to the age of my Mac, I cannot download the iCloud app. So my only options are to email it to myself or go on my computer, go to the iCloud website, sign-on and get the document that way. When I brought this up to the Apple worker, he stated that the iPad is capable of printing directly from the iPad as an option as well. So that minimized my concerns. Over all, I am very happy with the decision I made, all my questions regarding the iPad have been able to be answered with a simple google-search. One of the best spur-of-the-moment purchases I have ever made.
Works great and saved a few bucks.  I really am glad I got my IPad. It does so much more than what I had imagined.
i don't have to use my laptop and it not going to burn out as fast. its great for game, messages, mail, moves and so much more.battery life is good,

I was given an older version IPAD from my brother last year and really liked it but it only worked on Wi-Fi. I don't live in an area where Wi-Fi is always available so I was limited to using it at home. so a few months later when my 50th birthday was coming up, my husband asked what I would like. I told him the only thing I wanted was the IPad with wireless AND 3G. Of course he thought I was nuts since I had a perfectly good, working IPAd already. So naturally, I got my wish!  We ordered a refurbished one to save money. I have not been disappointed yet! I take it everywhere with me. I am impressed with the speed even when using 3G. I am able to use it at our cabin and streamed our High School basketball State Championship game with zero problems.  The only problem I have now is I own a 5 month old Laptop that I rarely use!

Chances are, you know what an iPad is and know the positives of it. It is very user friendly, it has tons of apps, and they are all ran through Apple so they work very well. There are occasional crashes with streaming app, but it only closes the app and you can reopen it. This is the iPad 2, so, if you are expecting Siri... you will be disappointed. Siri is nice, but it isn't needed to love this product. The maps is still awful, but you can get Google maps and that is much better. Realistically, this is wonderful for people who do a lot of internet based surfing and want a phone experience but bigger. It is also great for family that is horrible with tech. If you are wondering, "Well, I'm a power user, is there anything for me?" Firstly, you should know how to look that up yourself. Secondly, yes! You can VPN into a laptop or desktop with many apps available in the app store to Virtualize your desktop from any wifi access point. Great buy and if money is a problem, the iPad 2 is now cheap enough to not be a big purchase.

I've always been a bit eclectic in terms of the hardware and software of my various electronic devices. I have a laptop running Ubuntu, a 2008 iMac desktop (I got it as a birthday present mere weeks before the '09 model debuted), I've used many Android devices (two phones and a tablet), and the only e-book reader I've ever used is a Kindle.

That having been said, after using the iPad, I'm completely won over to Apple. The build quality is superior to other products, the interface is smooth and responsive, and the software library (as is well known at this point) is incomparably large.

First of all I have to say that Apple knows how to make elegant, beautiful devices that are packed with power and features.

My iPad has been with me since day one, I use it everyday for research, readings, logging on to my schools system, and also typing up documents on Pages, and creating presentations on Keynote. I usually charge once a night, and that one charge lasts for hours. Its such a great device, very useful and helps lessen the load I carry around. I have also downloaded study help apps and homework apps that keep me up to date on what assignments I have coming up.

I would recommend this product for everyone. The controls are simple enough for even my parents to understand (lol, I love them, but they're a little slow on the technological uptake), but the functions it provides and the apps that can be added are able to provide complex operations tailored to suit any need.

The battery life is amazing. I can use it almost continuously for approximately twenty hours before I need to reuse it. Less if I'm using heavy graphics, etc. But even then it functions for around sixteen hours. It charges very quickly when turned off and plugged into the wall. The screen is very responsive, and the keyboard is not as difficult to use as I had feared (this is referring to the larger keyboard that appears when you turn the device side-ways. The smaller keyboard is more difficult, but not impossible). The only downside I see to the keyboard is that I can't select Spanish letters and accents. I hear that there may be a way to get them, but I haven't had success thus far.

All in all, a wonderful device. I love it, and would buy it again.

I bought this iPad for my two sons who are 5 and 3 because I was sick of them changing the settings and doing weird stuff to my laptop even with windows live family safety installed. This was my best purchase of the decade. The parental controls are amazing. I have Safari, iTunes, App Store, etc. all disabled. They have about 13 movies, 64 apps (mostly educational apps for letter tracing, coloring, baby Spanish, and so on), 28 books, and even Netflix for the weekends. They learned how to use it VERY QUICKLY! Within a day of showing them how to do stuff no more than once, they've pretty much mastered it. I have an Otterbox Defender case on it because they do abuse it quite a bit. When watching Netflix I hook it up to the TV so they don't have to worry about holding it. When we do leave the house and are away from WIFI they have plenty of content to keep them happy, esp in the car on long trips.

However, I just installed Windows 8 on my PC and I hate it so much I am considering selling it and purchasing an iPad for myself.

I'm also saving up to get one for my 67 year old daddy whom calls me weekly asking me how to get the sound and video back working on Skype and how to get back to his FB page on his laptop. Some people just don't need a lot of settings to control!

I always thought the iPad was kinda stupid. It seemed like an overgrown iPod touch and nothing more. My mind is now changed. I live in a very rural area and internet service is 80-90$ a month and extremely slow. So I had an idea "hey, what if I use the 3G on an iPad as a supplement to wifi in my area. Turns out Verizon works great in my area and it is only 30$ a month with NO CONTRACT. I had no idea you could get 3G without a contract, for me that really sealed the deal. Now I am using Internet that is actually FASTER then wifi in my area!  Since in am savings 50-60$ a month, the savings will pay for the device in 10months and end up saving me hundreds upon hundreds of dollars. I love it!

The Internet is surprisingly easy to navigate and the touch keyboard is much easier to use then I thought it would be. If you are in an area where Internet is pricy and all you really do is surf the web, consider getting an iPad as an Internet device. I am pretty sure you can tether it to a laptop anyways and use Internet.

For me, the iPad is an important, practical and HUGE money saving device !!!

Owning both the iPad 2 and iPad 3, there really isn't much of a difference unless you use 4G/LTE or want to play the very very select few games that run better on the iPad 3.  The iPad 2 doesn't heat up.  The iPad 3 does.  The iPad 2 is a bit thinner and lighter (not much but notable).  Contrary to what I'd expected, the 2540x1480 screen is almost useless.  You still browse the web at only 720x1280, and most other commonly-used tasks.  Only a handful of games are made for 2540 resolution; therefore, it's practically useless given the iPad 2 is nearly half the price of the 3rd and 4th generation (which are both too similar to distinguish). While the A4/A5/A6 processors differ, it doesn't translate into real life differences in overall performance for watching videos, mail, web browsing, etc.  IMO the iPad 2 is s till the best tablet to come out in the past 3 years given that it's about half the price as those of its successors.

Ok it took me a while to jump on the Apple bandwagon, but I finally did.  Although I purchased a used Ipad2 (didn't want to still pay 500.00) I have to say it is worth it.  I have 2 kids 8 and 4 and as I told my father, there is just something about a device that you hand to your 4 year old and he can figure out how to use it.  He definitely knows more than my husband.  I use it for games e-mail, news.  My kids do games, math, watch Disney shows and fight over it, so much so that I might have to get another one but I am still not willing to spend full price will probably still look for a used model, works great for us.

We got this iPad because it can read my husbands text books out loud to him (which helps with the absorption of the massive amounts of material he has to read for grad school) but the rest of us have fallen in love with it too. I like it because its quick and easy to grab and read blogs or look up a recipe and its not nearly as hard to type on as I was afraid it might be. And it is my very best friend when it comes to road tripping with our 3 year old. Road trips went from being a terror to a very enjoyable experience with the iPad (We got an Otterbox Defender case to keep it safe when the kid has it).

Why? Compare two things and you will know. Time and Living. If these two matter to you, then look at how convenient it is to use an Apple based appliance. Some say intuitive. I say easy. Basic. There are so many reviews of the ipad I decided to talk about some things I love about it that many don't already know.
All of these favorite things work on the iphone as well.
I love the iPad and one of my favorite things it can do is take a screen shot or photo of anything on your screen anytime you want just by pushing the home button and the power button at the top at the same time.  This means that when you get a map of where you are going later, you can take a screen shot that will go right to your photos (camera roll) and then you can go there and email or text it to anyone else so they have a map to meet you there! You can do this with anything on your screen!!!! What a fantastic tool!
Another thing I love that people don't often know about is in the settings, general, accessibility section there are two things you can just turn on and they will read you almost anything out loud on your iPad!  One of them was created for differently abled people and one is more basic.  Speak over and Auto Text are the ones to look for respectively if you'd like to try these! They do take some getting used to.
One other thing I learned late in my use of this is that when you are looking at emails, you do not have to open them before deleting them.  If you just swipe your finger across one you know is spam a delete button will come up and you can delete it without ever opening it.
I will add more fun tips as I learn them myself!

Electronics have become part of our everyday life. They help to define who we are by being a source of connection to the world. An iPad is what has been my connection and has transformed my life exceedingly. It also enhanced every aspect of my life in many unique ways. My iPad 2 is reliable, family/school friendly and has also served as a memory book for me.
Apple has been in existence for decades, since 1976, and has grown to become our apple and nutrition of the day providing us iPhones, Macs, iPods and iPads. Apple has become a very trustworthy brand. Before I purchased the iPad on Amazon I needed to confirm that it was going to be worth my time, effort and money. I was blown away by the results of the reviews it had obtained throughout the years. Most of the reviews had given it a five star rating. At that point I knew I needed to buy my iPad 2. I anticipated its arrival anxiously because of the great qualities the product had. In the end, it was everything I had imagined it to be.
My brothers fell in love with it as much as I did, or possibly even more. I started exploring my iPad, downloading games and taking pictures. I am amazed at how much one little device can calm and contain children. I have four hyper active brothers and sisters and my iPad has worked miracles on them. They all sit down and as one quietly plays on the iPad, the others patiently wait for their turn. Before my siblings would be jumping and running around everywhere, yelling and fighting about everything. After that point my mom always carried my iPad and she is now buying one for herself. My iPad has become very helpful when it comes to school. I can take notes on it. I complete my homework on it.as type up my essays; watch instructive videos, take educational pictures and much more.  It also converts to a television on weekends. The screen is big enough to watch movies on it, browse Netflix and watch almost anything else. I have grown an emotional connection with my iPad and if you have a family or go to school, I know it will be the perfect product for you as well because it has the capability of helping one though any struggle that may arise.
Not only is it an amazing device because of the things it can do but it is also easy to carry around. It is very portable and lightweight compared to carrying a laptop. A laptop does not have the same durability as an iPad. The iPad will hold many memories; it will be like a digital scrapbook that you can easily access and always retain. The iPad memory is what preserves those special moments with your pets, family and anything that is very dear to your heart. The iPad may be purchased with different types of memory according to what it will be used for. Also because it is so transportable it has a great battery capacity, making the life of the iPad longer. Lastly, the iPad's 2 cameras will capture many memorable and wonderful moments. The camera captures clear and vivid images that will last a lifetime.
My iPad has been a huge focus in my life. I believe it will be a long lasting item that I will not become bored of or toss in the corner like another abandoned electronic. I will always feel confident in recommending this item and what better place to purchase it than Amazon. Amazon has everything for a better, cheaper price; it is dependable and has the option for fast shipping if needed. My life truly has been blessed by this prodigious electronic. I agree with most people that this item deserves a five star rating. It has been two years since I have bought my iPad and I continue to be a very happy costumer, and will continue to be a consumer of apple products in the future.

Received in a timely manner, package contained everything as expected and it is a GREAT tablet!! My entire family uses it for games, finances, reading and educational tools. If you have the money, I would certainly suggest you purchase an IPAD

So first let me say I looked and drooled over the iPad 2 for what felt like forever!!! It came to a cross roads where my husband said if you can prove to me that you need it you can get it... Well need and want are two very different things but I justified the purchase by listing all the functions and daily life the iPad would help with. From movies, music, books, shows, orginization, games and productivity, the iPad has made waves throughout my house. It is easy to use, even for the kiddos and has provided our family with a great helper on long trips. Some of the apps are expensive but that is okay when you are choosy with your needs. Most apps have a free version. I have gotten pretty fast on the keyboard. The iPad connects easily to available wifi and makes using the feature painless. I love my iPad! I reccomend a case immediately! With an investment such as this you can't be too careful. Usually you can find them online or in discount stores. Because the model is the same size as the previous iPad and will likely be the same as the iPad 3 screen protectors need not be outrageously priced. I have had issues finding all the books and magazines I thought there would be, however I expect in short order there will be releases. Apple is always coming out with new and innovative products, accessories and updates. Great purchase!!! I am very satisfied. I am a Android lover, and iPad almost has me convinced I need an iPhone on my next go-round!! We shall see! If you don't have an iPad, don't hesitate, get it, it is well worth the price.

I've had my iPad, which I bought used, since the end of April 2012.  I bought it to read articles (both academic PDF's and online fare via Instapaper) and play silly games, and it has exceeded my expectations on both counts.  I had used both a 7" and 10" Android tablet (modded Nook Color and gTablet, respectively) and a 4th generation iPod Touch in the past for pretty much the same purposes as with the iPad, and found myself not turning them on and subsequently selling them, so I was skeptical of how useful I'd find the iPad vs. a laptop or desktop.

The advantage over the iPod Touch is just a matter of real estate.  The interfaces of the universal apps that I've used (ones that are available on both the iPod Touch and iPad) are much better on the iPad.  Not to knock Android, because I was admittedly using heavily modded versions of it and didn't have access to the entire Market (now Google Play, I guess), but there really are a ton of good apps available on the App Store.  There are good, efficient implementations of board games, silly puzzle games, a perfectly fine browser experience, good Dropbox, Instapaper, and Evernote apps; I could go on, but, really, there are just a ton of ways to use the iPad well.  I don't use it for much productivity (outside of Evernote and Dropbox), so I couldn't speak to that aspect.  But as a fun device that's useful to me, it's easy to recommend it to others.  If you want to spend the extra $100 for retina display, sure, go ahead and get the third generation one.  If you're struggling between the iPad 2 and other companies' tablets, though, I say go with the Apple.

I love my iPad. It is so easy to use and so useful. I bought the one without the cellular data ability. I didn't want to have to pay for a data plan and saved money on the cost of the iPad. That was the right choice for me. I use it all over the place with free wi fi spots so widely available. There are so many apps available that you can customize it for your needs very easily. This almost replaces my laptop computer. I hardly ever turn on the laptop anymore. The iPad runs faster than my laptop on most things online. I bought my iPad after falling in love with the one that I was issued for use in my special education class. I have been totally amazed at the things that I have seen happening in my classroom with the iPad. Any teacher, homeschoolers, or parent should have at least one iPad strictly for the kids. They are great learning tools with so many educational apps available--most free or low cost. And if you have a special needs child or student, then you doubly need an iPad for their use. It is much easier to use than a conventional computer for special needs children. And if you have a child with any disability on the Autism spectrum than you absolutely, without a doubt MUST have an iPad for your child. There are hundreds of apps designed just for people with Autism. If for no other reason than to use as an augmented communication system device, you must get this for your child with Autism.

If I am asked to name one flaw with the iPad, it is that it cannot be cleaned. The screen gets lots of finger prints and gunk on it--especially with children using it. And it will get scratches on the screen, no matter how careful you are. If using it in a classroom with lots of children it can be a germ breeding ground since you cannot wipe it down with disinfectant. At school, we stick them inside gallon zip close storage bags as a good protective covering that can be thrown out and replaced cheaply. Screen protectors are a must have accessory.

Most of the reviewers have given all the pros and cons, so I won't bore you with another list here. Like most people, I use the iPad 90% of the time on just a few Apps. For me, reading an ebook, checking stock quotes, and reading the news constitute most of what I do. It's good to have half a million Apps, but it's impossible to use that many, or even a fraction of that. I've compared the iPad to the Kindle for reading ebooks. For me, the iPad is the clear winner. In my opinion, the iPad is easier to read and is sharper, also the color is a plus. The Kindle is hard to read in low light. Maybe if you are outside, the Kindle would have the edge, but I never read outside, and I think most people don't (possibly some do at the beach). I have an iPad 1 with WiFi and 3G, and an iPad 2 with WiFi only. I think the WiFi is the way to go because of the cost savings. Sometimes the 3G is nice, but I don't use it that often. Bottom line, I can recommend either model. It's reliable, easy to use, and Apple has the updates to improve things or fix any bugs that crop up.

Yes Apple has released the new iPad (or what the rest of us call the iPad 3). Apple Marketing, please think about your naming conventions in the future! But I still love my iPad 2!

I use my iPad 2 just about every day. I mainly use it for reading email when I don't feel like pulling out the Macbook Pro. I also use it as an eReader (Amazon, Nook, Safari Books online, MacTech magazine, iBooks, etc). No it's not the retina display. But if you can't afford the retina display this is the next best thing. I can read this one just fine, so no upgrading for me.

I didn't choose one with a data plan (would have been 3G when I bought this - last year), but I don't find that I need one. One hint on the data: If you can find a decent mifi data plan then you can just get the wifi version of the iPad and be done with it. Even so, I find wifi hotspots all over the place (including my house of course, which is where I use it a lot).

The camera is ok, but I use my iPhone for pics, so I really don't care. They could have substituted the camera for some other feature and I would have been just as happy.

It is an awesome game platform as it gives you more space to play with. It also works great with the Apple TV and streaming audio.

Yes, Android tablets are catching up, but they still aren't there yet. They don't have the price point of an iPad nor the consistency of the user experience.

The iPad is also a durable product: I have dropped mine, and only had small cracks appear on the bezel, with no affect on performance whatsoever. Still I recommend some kind of case. The smart cover is good, but doesn't protect the back. I'm still looking for my ultimate case.

I have made it through an entire plane ride (cross-country 6 hr trip) without running down the battery completely.

I'll start by being brutally honest here and admit that initially I doubted Apple's Ipad when it was initially released in 2010. I didn't see much utility for it and frankly thought it was a bit silly and I wasn't all for it. I didn't see much use for it although I recognized it was a nifty, cool little device but thought it was a bit too much like an Ipod touch. Forward to 2012 I now am the owner of an Ipad 2 and loving it, I'm converted. It wasn't until I had the opportunity to spend time experimenting and playing with the tablet that I saw myself using it me and bringing it along with me, in short wanting one. I've owned an Ipad for a little over two weeks and with this time passed by I've had enough time to enjoy and experiment enough with this device that now seems to be the right time to review it. If you must know I went for the Ipad 2 simply because I liked how remarkably slim and light it was and although the Ipad 3 has the new retina display, to me it didn't significantly expand the second generation of Apple tablets for me to pay a hundred dollars more (money is important after all and is a deciding factor) to have the "new" product I decided. I read reviews and articles, comparisons between the second and third generations of Ipad and came to the conclusion that I'd be well off with 16 GB Ipad 2 and from then on would decide whether or not to upgrade to one of the future Ipads depending on my use and enjoyment of the tablet.

You can say all you want but no one presents and markets a product quite like Apple is capable of (and does). They're often criticized for how expensive their products are yet they are everywhere and well designed and thought and they're hard to ignore.  Apple had success with the Mac and Mac book and their different models, the Ipod, the Iphone (all with variations and updated models of the same product) and more recently with the Ipad. I'll be the first to admit Apple's gadgets and electronic devices can be expensive but I've also never had a problem with any apple product I've owned in the past.

The size is one of the best thing about the Ipad, it's neither too big nor too small and the screen is big, bright and clear and there's just so much you can do. The interface is excellent; it feels and works great, looks neat and simplistic and it's very easy to catch on. It just feels natural and anyone from a child to a grandparent can use it and understand the bare basics an enjoy it. The applications or "apps" as they are called are truly what MAKE the Ipad the innovative device that it is, otherwise it does a lot of what your Iphone/Ipod touch or Laptop/Desktop do which is still keep in mind, excellent. There are ton of apps for different needs be it for reading books and magazines, to taking notes, playing fun games and everything in between. There are ton of apps already on the market, some brilliant and very useful to some downright stupid and new ones are constantly being created. Many apps are free, not most but a good quantity are and the range from the 0.99-1.99-2.99-3.99... 9.99 etc.  There are apps that serve as business tools, diverse utilities, fun mindless games like the popular Angry Birds, there's Safari as the internet browser, you can set up you e-mail accounts, manage your bank account, make hotel reservations etc. The list goes on please believe! There's of course Itunes from which you can buy music, movies and more and have them uploaded instantly to your Ipad. You can also sync it to any existing Itunes account and select material to upload to the device. I also like that there is both an inward and outward camera like on the Iphone so you can take pictures of anything you see or yourself which is a very nice option I thought I'd mention.  Those programs and apps are all stored in your Ipad via the memory it contains whether it's 16, 32 or 64 GB and ultimately the amount of Gigabytes you have determines how much content can be stored on the Ipad. The battery life is roughly ten hours (of course depending on certain factors such the brightness, volume etc.) which is not bad at all and still better than my laptop.

These are just a few thoughts and suggestions if you're considering purchasing an Ipad.

-  For me just the Wi-Fi model was fine. However, if you're often on the go and have a need for internet that can't wait and need it "right now" all the time without close Wi-Fi access available at all times then maybe you should consider getting a 3G model for just a little more $ with a monthly or pre-paid plan.

-Another thing you might want to consider is the memory you're going to need. The 16G model has in reality 13.9 G (there is always a certain portion of available storage taken before even touch it) and I think for the average user this will be fine (besides you can always remove apps etc. and it does keep track of whatever you've downloaded in case you want it back). Most apps don't take up a whole lot of storage room although some are bigger than others. The same with music, it depends how much you plan to use the Ipad for music and this also applies to the books you buy and how many you plan to buy keep (although the books aren't as bad as the music and movies as far as I'm concerned, I wouldn't worry too much unless you're a hardcore reader who plans to store plenty of books).  If you're planning to upload a lot of movies or have/use a lot of data then perhaps a 32G or 64G model would be a better fit for you considering how movies can easily be over 1GB each. They're more expensive of course but may warrant the consideration if you'd rather have the larger number of Gigabytes but and not take the available space entirely than have one that's filled up soon after.

-If you're interested in owning the latest thing and see potential great things about the Ipad 3 like the retina display and the upgraded processor you may want to go ahead with the newer model. Otherwise the second generation Ipad makes a viable option if you want to save a bit of money, other than that the two devices are basically identical and at first look no one could notice a difference between the 2 and 3. If you're considering either I suggest you do some research as I did, especially if money is an important factor in your decision and then decide for yourself which one it is you want.

-Another somewhat big decision is the color choice, whether you want a black Ipad or a white one. Personally I went with the white one as I liked how it looked and it seems to me that most people I know own the black. The color is not all that important it's what it can do and the options it gives you although some will insist on owning either one color or the other.

-Last you may want to protect the Ipad with a protective screen just in case (it's always better to be prepared) to protect it. You may want to consider purchasing a nice case to store and carry it and maybe even a stylus pen if you think you might be into that type of thing.

In a world where tablets are rapidly and steadily selling Apple's Ipad has in reality very little competition partly due to clever marketing but mostly due to the great product they delivered.  Don't have a lot of negatives, if any, to say for the most part I am really liking it and find myself using it every single day and it nearly replaces my laptop. It does close to everything I want to do with my laptop usually, for me the Ipad is now one of those things tht I can't live without (not literally but still!).  I made the jump and find myself enjoying the Ipad and like it for its portability which makes it great for travelling and carrying wherever I go. It's entertaining, useful and smooth.  I like that I can have so much in one convenient sized device that doesn't take up a whole lot of space, can access wi-fi, check my e-mails, play games and more. It's not as big or heavy as a laptop, does not overheat even when running for several hours and opens MUCH faster yet it's not so small that it's inconvenient to type or a little hard to read (or touch in the case of my cellular phone) and do tasks with a cell phone, it's a perfect balance if you will. I really don't have anything negative to say about my Ipad, it would be nice in the future to have place for a USB/SD slot and I believe that may be coming eventually.  Obviously I've been praising the Ipad a lot  and I don't regret my purchase, full marks *****.
